PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat,-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National AIDS Program: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are offended and outraged by the direction of the AIDS Programme in Tasmania, in that it actively promotes Homosexual Acts and in particular anal intercourse, and that taxpayers money is being used to fund literature which directly promotes homosexual behaviour as a normal and desirable human activity.

Your petitioners therefore urgently and strongly request that the Federal Government and the Minister for Health review the National AIDS Programme and withdraw funding for this literature, and from any other aspects of the AIDS Campaign which encourages or condones anal intercourse.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.

We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. they are aware it properly reflects the immutable characters of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. they recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Tropical Timber
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We your petitioners do humbly request that the Government,
place an immediate ban on the import of all tropical timber.

Throughout the world tropical rainforest is being cleared at a catastrophic pace. The Earth is now losing its tropical forests at the rate of 7% a year and the end of almost all the planet's rainforests is now in sight.

Scientists estimate 200 species of fauna and flora are forced into extinction everyday. This is primarily due to habitat destruction which for the majority of the world's species is tropical rainforest.
Scientific evidence is also overwhelming that tropical rainforest destruction is playing a significant part in increasing the greenhouse effect.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to amend the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act 1986 and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Act 1985, to give effect to Government decisions announced in the economic statement of 12 April 1989. The intent of the proposed amendments is both to terminate subsidy schemes as from 12 April 1989 and to broaden the eligibility for assistance under the Grain Harvesters and Equipment Act to include harvesters and harvester equipment held in stock as at 12 April 1989, similar to provisions which apply to the cultivation machines and equipment scheme.

As outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the April economic statement, the Government is determined to ensure that fiscal policy is kept tight in order to maintain downward pressure on Australia's trade deficit. To that end, the Government has decided to implement a number of savings measures which will be incorporated in the August 1989 Budget. These savings are intended to offset the cost of the measures announced in the economic statement which will assist families and pensioners.

In view of these strong budgetary pressures, the Government considers it would be inappropriate to exempt outlays associated with industry assistance and development. In the Government's view, the most appropriate means of effecting the necessary savings in this area is to terminate the grain harvesting and cultivation equipment assistance schemes. Neither of these schemes has made a contribution commensurate with its cost towards achievement of the Government's policy goal of creating internationally competitive and export oriented Australian industries.

The Government has put in place a range of positive assistance measures aimed at improving the efficiency and international competitiveness of our manufacturing sector which have been available to the grain harvester and cultivation equipment manufacturing sectors. These include the heavy engineering program, the 150 per cent research and development tax incentives, grants for industrial research and development and a range of extension services through the national industry extension service.
Financial Impact Statement
The termination of the two agricultural machinery assistance schemes will result in savings of $19m during 1989-90 and $10.4m during 1990-91. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

RESPONSE BY MR C. WYATT AGREED TO BY MR WYATT AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5 (7) (b) OF THE SENATE OF 25 FEBRUARY 1988
On Thursday, 9 March 1989, Senator Crichton-Browne addressed the Senate on the Special Audit Report on the Aboriginal Development Commission and Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
The Senator said:

. . . the [Aboriginal Affairs] Department did not have in place a program, policy or system which allowed it to assess whether or not the funds were being used for the purpose for which they were intended. It is not without significance to note that in Western Australia, when we had this absolute imbroglio, confusion, chaos, incompetence and, in some cases, corruption, the departmental head was Cedric Wyatt, who for his sins was promoted by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, to the position of General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). At a time of apparent crisis in the ADC, when new, competent and efficient management was needed, it got a personally hand-picked appointment who had reigned over the Department in Western Australia, which the Auditor-General referred to in the report in a most scathing way. I put it down as nothing higher than gross inefficiency and incompetence. (Hansard pp. 788-89)

The Senator used the words `incompetence' and `corruption' and I do most vehemently object to my name and reputation being abused in that context. I take great pride in having served the Government of Australia faithfully and enthusiastically in the Public and Armed Services for over 25 years. My present field of employment as a private consultant in government and Aboriginal Affairs depends very much on a sound administrative reputation and moral integrity beyond reproach. I totally reject criticisms of incompetence and, as to allegations of corruption, I am most distressed that an ordinary citizen as myself, and I do unequivocally reject such accusation, should be slandered in this way in such an honourable institution as the Senate.

Aboriginal leaders, myself included, cannot be expected to right the wrongs of colonial maladministration of Aboriginal people in a short period of time. Aboriginal communities, some of them still very tribal, cannot be expected to become proficient in commercial operations overnight. As a senior public servant I could see and clearly understand these difficulties, and exercises in liberality on my part should not be slandered as `incompetence' and `corruption' in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now has before it the Arts, Territories and Environment Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. This is essentially a machinery Bill and makes a number of minor amendments to quite a variety of Acts which fall within the portfolio of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and which relate to legislation as it affects external territories of Australia, about which my colleague, Senator Boswell, will speak, and the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The purposes of the legislation may be summarised as follows: First, to allow the Australian Film Commission, the National Museum of Australian and the Australian Heritage Commission to conduct formal meetings by telephone or video conference; secondly, to permit the Australia Council, the Australian Film Commission, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Australian National Gallery and the National Museum to invest moneys, although only in those areas currently provided for in their respective pieces of legislation, without having to seek approval of the Minister for each specified investment; thirdly, to reduce membership of the Council of the Australian Film, Television and Radio School from 15 persons to nine; fourthly, to clarify aspects of the operation of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 to remove duplications arising from the current need to obtain both the Federal and the State permit for dumping, so that approved State permit systems will be sufficient within State coastal waters, and to make substantial increases-in some cases of up to $250,000-for unauthorised dumping of wastes, especially hazardous wastes, at sea; and, finally, in the arts and environment area, to amend the Sea Installations Act 1987 to improve its operation in a number of technical aspects regarding permits and environmental impact statement procedures and to provide for representation of Norfolk Island in appropriate meetings.

As I say, the Bill also has some relevance to the portfolio area of external Territories and the Australian Capital Territory where it provides a mechanism for dealing with the collection of fines from people who failed to vote at ACT elections-a new system which might be regarded as on the spot fines for non-voting in the Australian Capital Territory. The Opposition has no objection to any of the provisions of this Bill, although I want to make a few brief comments.

The Opposition is pleased to see that bodies such as the Australian Film Commission, the National Museum of Australia and the Australian Heritage Commission are catching up with the modern technology which is available to allow conference meetings to be held by use of telephone or video. That is a very useful amendment to the legislation because it will ensure that, where these bodies have representation drawn from around Australia, they will be able to participate in necessary meetings without the requirement for all parties to be physically in the same place at the same time, which presumably means a cost saving may be effected. Secondly, we are glad to see the increased financial flexibility extended to the Australia Council, the Australian Film Commission, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Australian National Gallery and the National Museum of Australia to invest moneys in approved areas without having to seek the approval of the Minister for each specified investment. It is interesting that the upper limit of the investment varies quite considerably between these institutions. For example, the upper limit for the Australia Council's investment without ministerial approval is $50,000; for the Australian Film Commission, it is $250,000; for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the sum is $50,000; for the Australian National Gallery, the amount is $100,000; and, for the National Museum of Australia, it is $100,000.

The Opposition is certainly very supportive of the amendments made to increase the penalties provided under the Environmental Protection (Sea Dumping) Act to ensure that people who are responsible for the dumping of wastes at sea in an improper and unauthorised manner are now faced with potential fines of up to $250,000. There is a worldwide concern manifest equally in Australia that the protection of the sea is becoming a more important item on the environmental agenda. Fines should be realistic and should sufficiently deter individuals and companies from undertaking such irresponsible activities.

The amendments to the Sea Installations Act will improve its operations in a number of technical aspects, particularly regarding the issue of permits and EIS procedures, and will provide representation for Norfolk Island in appropriate circumstances.

I turn to the matter of the reduction of the membership of the Council of the Australian Film, Television and Radio School from 15 to nine. We have no objection to that action but this is an opportunity to put on record one of the more extraordinary incidents revealed by Estimates Committee investigation into the financial priorities of the Government and the question of cost efficiency of Government operations.

In a meeting of Estimates Committee D on 13 April 1989, I had the chance to examine the accounts and the forward estimates of the Film, Television and Radio School and to ask questions of its Director, Mr O'Hara. In effect, the Film, Television and Radio School came to the Parliament and asked for an additional $16,000 for a staff position. When one examined what that $16,000 was for, it was found to be for the collection of fees under the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act. In the Estimates Committee hearing, I asked Mr O'Hara the following question:

You are requesting $16,000 to meet costs associated with the collection of fees, under the Higher Education Funding Act. Would you explain that to me. Is that $16,000 which you are requiring in order to collect fees?
The transcript continues:

Mr O'Hara-I think it is $12,000 that we are requesting for the collection of HECS, and $4,000 which is an adjustment to expense allowances for the chairman and the director. The $12,000 for the collection of fees is basically to provide for some administrative assistance and some PC support to enable us to collect the fees for our 40 students who are subjected to those fees. I understand that the Department of Employment, Education and Training has made some $1.5m available to tertiary institutions but, of course, we are not in a position to benefit from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do you collect by way of fees?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Hara-We have so far collected two fees up front, and the rest have opted to pay on the tax system.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not answer my question. How much have you collected?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Hara-It is $1,800 per annum, so I guess we have collected $3,600.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much are you going to collect?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Hara-We will collect, depending upon what students elect to pay up front, $1,800 per year per student.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do you anticipate collecting in a full year?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Hara-We would not anticipate collecting, at the moment, very much more than has already been collected this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is $3,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Hara-It is $3,500.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you are asking for $12,000 in order to collect $3,000?

SPEECH.PARA: That is, in fact, the correct assessment of the position. The Film Television and Radio School has come to the Parliament and asked it to appropriate $12,000 to pay an officer to collect $3,000 per year. If the Government were to run the whole of its operations on the basis that, in order to collect $3,000 one spends $12,000, the sort of economic management that it is indulging in at the moment would appear actually to be sophisticated by comparison. It is absolutely ludicrous to have an area within the arts portfolio, as pressed for money as that portfolio is at the moment, asking for an appropriation from the Parliament of $12,000 in order to collect $3,000 per year from two students. But that is what the Parliament has been asked to provide. It is ludicrous in the extreme.

Not only is there the question of whether organisations such as the Film, Television and Radio School and the various other bodies within the arts portfolio, such as the National Institute of Dramatic Art and similar institutions, should be required to enforce the payment of this levy by their students; there is also the question of why they do not have access to some of the $1.5m that the Department of Employment, Education and Training has made available to other tertiary institutions. I put it to the Minister, who, I am sure, will recognise the ludicrous nature of this proposition in having to fund an institution, that the provision of an extra $12,000-money which that institution could well use in any number of genuinely productive areas of its undertaking-in order to collect $1,800-a-year fees from two of its students, yielding the Commonwealth a net loss on the transaction of $9,000, really does seem to be unbelievably stupid.

Nevertheless, as I said in opening, this is a machinery piece of legislation. The Opposition certainly has no difficulty with any of the specific provisions. As I have said, my colleague Senator Boswell will be making some comments about the external territories aspect of the legislation. I conclude, therefore, on behalf of my other colleague Senator Hill, who has responsibility as shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory, by saying simply that we believe that there is some merit in the provision for the collection of on the spot fines from people who fail to vote under the required legislation in the Australian Capital Territory. We have no difficulties with the amendments which are being made to Territory legislation in that regard. I do not believe that it is necessary to detain the Senate any further on this piece of legislation.

I would like to address my attention to the amendments to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 which, as Senator Puplick has said, will make it easier for those who have not voted to pay a penalty-in this case $20-directly to the Electoral Commissioner without having to go through the courts. I can see why, in the last ACT election, some people might not have wanted to vote. It was certainly run under a very strange voting system which really did not please anybody.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see, as an amendment to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act, a change in the voting system itself. If we purport to have a democracy in Australia, I think it behoves us to use electoral systems which will reflect the will of the people. The d'Hondt electoral system simply does not. Everybody agrees that the d'Hondt system is a disaster. What should we have in place of it?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hare-Clark system.

—As my colleague from Tasmania has said, the Hare-Clark system-the Tasmanian system which is also used in Ireland. The Government Whip, Senator McKiernan, who does not have his green tie on today, is acknowledging the fact that it is used in Ireland. That system is also used in other well advanced civilisations around the world. That system ensures that everybody has a voice. Under the present system of first past the post, single member electorates, at any one time half the electorate is disenfranchised because one party will get its member in and the other party or parties will not. Therefore, only about 50 per cent of the people are represented. In the Hare-Clark system, which, as I said, is used in Tasmania, each electorate has seven seats which means that there is a good chance that all shades of political persuasions will be represented, as is the case in the Senate. The Hare-Clark system, in a modified form, works in the Senate. It allows for the independents, the Democrats, the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party to have a voice. I think that is a healthy situation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another variation in Tasmania, that most progressive of States, which I think is very valuable and should be examined-that is, the Robson amendment brought in by Neil Robson, a Liberal member of the legislature. Under this system, the names on the ballot are rotated. The Australian Electoral Commission has no difficulty with this. The ballot papers are printed in such a way that everyone on a party list has the opportunity of being at the top of the ballot paper one-seventh of the time. This eliminates, to a great extent, the donkey vote; it also eliminates party factions stacking the ballot. In fact, it gives people a better chance of electing the representatives they wish.

So I urge the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, who is seated in the chamber-I am sure that he is taking all this in with great attention, and he is nodding his head in agreement-to take all this on board because I am sure that he is a man who wants the people of Australia to have the best possible representation. The implementation in the Australian Capital Territory of the Hare-Clark system which is employed in Tasmania, with the Robson amendment, would ensure that more people would be pleased to vote. They would not have to be driven to the polls by the threat of fines.

I think it would be a very good thing for the Government if it allowed the people of the ACT to vote upon this very system. The Government should allow the people of the ACT to have a referendum to see whether they favour the proportional representation system which is used in Tasmania. If the Government were fair dinkum about democracy it would have a referendum and perhaps give the people of the ACT the choice of the single-member electorate system as used in New South Wales or the multi-member electorate system as used in Tasmania. Let the people choose. I think that the people of the ACT, being an intelligent group of voters, would choose the Tasmanian system. I challenge the Government to give the people of the ACT the chance to choose their own form of electoral system and not have to suffer, like camels, the d'Hondt system which nobody wants. I will be interested to hear the Minister's response to these thoughts. I am sure that they will be thoughtful. Having said that, I indicate that the Australian Democrats will support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments of my colleague Senator Puplick and also to support the Arts, Territories and Environment Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. I would like to make some comments on the parts of the Bill that refer to the territories.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill firstly amends the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955 and the Supreme Court Ordinance 1955 of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to restore criminal trials by jury in the courts of this Territory. The Bill provides for a court to move the venue of a criminal trial on indictment from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to another State or Territory where necessary and for jurors to be summoned at the new venue using the States' jury lists. These provisions are essentially the same as those introduced into the Christmas Islands Act 1958 by the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act 1987 following a farcical attempt to conduct a murder trial on Christmas Island.

The Cocos (Keeling) Islanders, with whom we have made contact, have no disagreement with the Bill. But they did go to the trouble to point out that the population of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is very small and that they had some concerns. If a trial were held there it would make things very difficult because everyone is related and everyone knows each other. Whilst they had no objection to the Bill, they requested, if ever there was an occasion on which a trial was needed, that the trial be held in another State. This is because of the problem that they would have in arranging a jury with no connections to any of the people there. While this Bill allows for that, I wanted to have their concerns put on record. It is interesting to note that there has never been a criminal trial on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, so I have been informed. Let us hope that the people there can maintain such a good record.

This legislation also amends the Sea Installation Act 1987 to provide that a representative of the Norfolk Island Government is included in discussions concerning the granting of permission and exemptions under the Act in the waters off Norfolk Island. This is very important. The Norfolk Islanders, of course, appreciate that they will now have a voice on that board. They have no objections to the Bill.

The other areas that I want to touch on refer to the Government's administration of Christmas Island-I know that Senator McKiernan is very interested in this-and particularly the decision-making process it initiated to select a successor to the mining operation. The recent Federal Court judgment on the bid to have the Government's decision on a successor phosphate operator reviewed provided an independent comment. Although this challenge failed on legal grounds, the court's judgment was damning on the Territory's bureaucracy, the former Minister, Mr Punch, and the whole decision-making process. In short, Mr Justice French found that successive Ministers and their advisers were not above criticism. He found that the decision making process on the successor operator had been essentially political and the assessment's characterisation very similar to the fictitious Sir Humphrey Appleby on the program Yes, Minister.

Might I say that the new Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) seems to be at least trying to halt the malaise which infected the administration of Christmas Island during the period in office of his predecessors, Mr John Brown and Mr Punch. During this time the Territory's bureaucracy pursued its own agenda for Christmas Island. I believe that Mr Brown, as Minister, was more interested in tourism and other parts of his portfolio than the Territories.

What makes the Federal Court's criticism of Mr Punch even more damning is that throughout his period as responsible Minister the Opposition constantly advised him about what he should be doing and where his Department was misinforming him. The prime example of this was the so-called independent assessment of mining proposals by the liquidator of the Government's phosphate mining corporation, Mr Robert Yeomans. At the time of Mr Yeomans's appointment, the Opposition advised Mr Punch that the assessment should have been conducted by private consultants. Mr Braithwaite warned that there may be problems with Mr Yeomans's suitability and that should any such problems emerge Mr Punch could not say that he had not been warned.

I now wish to detail certain facts which should convince the new Minister and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), the Ministers responsible, that they have to keep an eye on the happenings on Christmas Island. In May 1988 the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories received advice from the Attorney-General's Department that Mr Yeomans could determine which of several proposals would provide the highest return on the assets of the Phosphate Mining Christmas Island Corporation but could not undertake a broad assessment to determine its commercial viability, except in so far as such matters may affect the capacity of a potential purchaser to pay or otherwise affect the winding up of the Corporation. In fact, Mr Yeomans's duties as assessor were not dissimilar to his duties as liquidator, that is, to achieve the highest return on the Corporation's assets.

After noting the proposal from the Booth Consortium and Elders Resources Ltd, both offered net payments of $500,000. Mr Yeomans stated that the Booth proposal offered slightly higher royalty payments. It follows that Mr Yeomans failed to follow the advice of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). He then proceeded to justify his recommendation of Elders by saying that its proposal was superior in a range of areas, all of which went to issues broader than the price and, therefore, deviated from the parameters set out in the advice of the Attorney-General. This is not a case of just a slight difference in royalty returns. I have been supplied with figures which show that under the worst case royalty payments from the Booth Consortium would amount to $11.74m, whereas under Elders' best case the Commonwealth would receive between $6.93m and $11.52m, depending on which option is used. This was because Elders' royalty proposal was a flat $1.70 per tonne for 10 years, whereas the Booth Consortium offer was a 5 per cent rate based on its selling price per tonne shipped.

At the Estimates Committee hearings I asked the Department if Mr Yeomans ever tried to get Elders to change its flat rate royalty proposal in an effort to negotiate a selling price figure and, if so, when. In other words, I asked: Did Mr Yeomans ever try to get Elders to change its offer to make it more like the Booth offer? The answer I received was, `Yes, departmental officers had been present at a number of meetings called by the liquidator and attended by Elders at which the flat rate royalty was discussed with a view to negotiating a system of indexed royalties'. All in all there were seven meetings, the first following hard on the heels of the announcement of Mr Yeomans's recommendation that the Government commence negotiation with Elders.

The second matter I wish to examine is the answer to a question I placed on notice about this matter. On 7 April 1989 I asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories the following question:

Did the liquidator: (a) recommend that proposal which would best maximise returns to the Commonwealth through both net payment and royalties; if not, why not; and (b) take into account matters extraneous to the parameters set out in the Attorney-General Department's advice.
Senator Richardson supplied the following answer:

The Liquidator recommended that proposal which would best maximise returns to the Commonwealth through both net payments and royalties, but was not concerned with such matters as the economic or social development of the Territory, . . . except in terms of Mr Punch's request to the liquidator with respect to consideration of various matters, and in so far as such matters may have affected the capacity of a potential purchaser to pay the Liquidator under the proposed arrangements for the sale of the Corporation's assets. This is regarded as being in accord with the advice given by A-G's on 12 May 1988.
In short, contrary to the Attorney-General's advice, Mr Yeomans did not accept the proposal which would maximise returns to the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.
—Senator Richardson says that it is not true. I accept that Senator Richardson is a man of the utmost integrity.
—I will answer it in a second.

—I will not continue with the rest of my contribution on this matter because it does go into some personalities. If the Minister can answer those questions, I would prefer not to go ahead. If I am not satisfied with the Minister's response, I will take this matter up at another appropriate time in the Senate, possibly in the adjournment debate. Senator Richardson appears to have some reference on this matter. I will listen to his comments with interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to touch on another matter affecting the territories, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands floating hotel. The proposed $37.5m hotel could generate up to $20m a year for the local community including $14m in wages and $6m in purchases from the local cooperative. As many as 90 Cocos (Keeling) Islanders could be employed. The 20,000-tonne floating hotel would accommodate 200 people and would comprise a restaurant and food outlets, a conference room and entertainment areas. It seems to me that tourism offers the best prospect for underpinning the Cocos economy. This proposal offers really the only meaningful employment on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands; yet it has taken the Minister up to nine months to reply to a detailed notice of intention which was requested from the proponent of the Cocos Island resorts. The proponent was then told that the environmental assessment branch of the Department considered it should recommend to the Minister that it conduct a full environmental impact study. Yet another commercial hotel has been allowed to be established on Direction Island, part of the Cocos (Keeling) group. I suggest to the Minister that if he really wants to help the Cocos Island economy he should look at ways of developing tourism. Procrastination and stalling will not get any hotels or those types of developments on those islands. It is costing the developers many hundreds of thousands of dollars to put up these proposals. Senator Richardson, as the responsible Minister, and his junior Minister are not helping the situation at all by procrastinating and not giving firm guidelines for these developments to go ahead.

We are now talking about the future of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. For example-I take these figures off the top of my head-I believe that the population has now been reduced from 2,000 to around 500 or 600 people. As an Opposition, we have a responsibility to point these things out to the Government. These territories have been given to us under world forums and we are responsible for ensuring that the living standards of these people are maintained. We are also responsible for providing jobs for the people. The continual procrastination in not letting these developments go ahead is causing a great deal of concern.

While I am on the subject of external territories, I would like to take this opportunity to express my thanks to members of the Norfolk Island Administration for their hospitality during my recent visit to Norfolk Island over Easter. Norfolk Island is an absolute utopia; it is a subtropical paradise. I certainly enjoyed my stay but, more to the point, I went there to listen to the people's concerns. I put on record that they are proud to be a Territory of Australia, but they see themselves as Norfolk Islanders and they want the responsibility of running that island. They are concerned that there is an ever-increasing intrusion by Commonwealth Government departments inflicting on these people laws and orders that are appropriate to Australia. Norfolk Island has a very small community. Only about 3,000 permanent residents live on the island. They pay no income tax and there are no telephone charges or rates and taxes. It is an absolute utopia. There is no unemployment on Norfolk Island. People are brought in from Australia to fill the jobs. The Norfolk Islanders are certainly concerned about the intrusion of the legislation that is being passed by both Houses of the Australian Parliament and inflicted on their territory.

The Minister should take note of the concerns of the Norfolk Island people. They do look after their own. There is no unemployment benefit as there is no unemployment. If there is likely to be unemployment the numbers of people who are brought in to do the jobs are reduced. An extended family looks after all personal problems and any contingencies. Most of the islanders are descendants of the Pitcairn Island people, predominantly the Christians, the Adams, the McCoys and the Nobbs. Once again I express my thanks to the Norfolk Island people. I believe that they are coming up to an election, possibly even this Saturday. I urge the Minister at the table to take note of their concerns about the ever increasing intrusion of the Australian Government on their Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In looking at the contributions this morning, it is pleasing to note that Opposition and Australian Democrat senators support the Bill. I would like to answer a number of the points made, in particular those made by Senator Boswell.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sanders referred to the Australian Capital Territory election, to the d'Hondt system and to his faith in the Hare-Clark system. It has always been my experience in politics to expect people to support systems which have elected them. The Hare-Clark system has not been unkind to Senator Sanders in the past. I can understand why he would wish to see that system spread, particularly now that he is seeking new directions in his career in territories very close to this Parliament. We have seen a reference to a parliamentary committee on the Australian Capital Territory election. Like other senators I anxiously await the results of that committee's deliberations.

I turn now to Senator Boswell and his reference to the Christmas Island mining proposal. In a question in the Senate only a few days ago I was asked by Senator Boswell whether or not an unsuccessful tenderer offered 30 per cent more, I think, in royalties than did the successful tenderer so that returns to the Commonwealth were not being maximised. I forget the words of the honourable senator's question, but it was along those lines. Today the honourable senator has said something similar. Let me go into some detail of these matters and what has been supplied to me. I will not comment on the court case, on who did what to whom. Given that there will be an appeal shortly, those matters are sub judice and I do not wish to canvass them now. I will do so at a later time if the honourable senator wishes me to. Given his interest in the matter, I think it would be appropriate if I went through the details.

The proposal accepted by the Commonwealth maximises returns to the Commonwealth, both through net payments for assets and for royalties. Tenders for the privatisation of the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island were assessed by the liquidator of the Corporation, Mr Yeomans, a chartered accountant and professional liquidator with the Duesburys organisation. Mr Yeomans recommended that the Minister give him approval in principle to negotiate with Elders Resources Ltd for the recommencement of mining. He also recommended that if, for any reason, negotiations were not satisfactorily concluded with Elders, they could be instituted with Mr John Booth, who submitted a tender on behalf of a consortium. There was also a third tenderer, Century Metals and Mining, again a consortium with some other interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Islanders.

—And Islanders, yes. The liquidator noted in his conclusions that the Elders proposal was superior both to Century and Booth in respect of financial resources, production and technical expertise, mainland support bases, research and development and quality of submission. In effect, he concluded that Elders was a major Australian public resources company and that it had the expertise and the back-up to deliver on its tender. That conclusion was consistent with the advice of the Attorney-General's Department to which Senator Boswell referred.
—They also said that Booth was an experienced performer and company.

—I do not think we are necessarily disputing that. I suppose it is a question of looking at who could best deliver. In the end, one always has to decide on a tender. The advice of the Attorney-General's Department of 12 May 1988, to which Senator Boswell referred, was that the liquidator should not be concerned with viability of proposals except in so far as such matters may have affected the capacity of a potential purchaser to pay the liquidator under proposed arrangements for the sale of the Corporation's assets.

SPEECH.PARA: The liquidator in the conclusions to his report also noted that both the Elders and Booth proposals provided for the same net payment to the liquidator for the assets of the Corporation. On the issue of royalties, he concluded the following:

Payment by Elders of royalties of $1.70 per tonne shipped, exceeds the offer contained in the Century proposal and compares favourably with the Booth proposal which, however, does offer slightly higher royalty payments.

But as well as the $1.70 per tonne Elders provided, as spelt out in its tender, there was $1 per tonne to be used for rehabilitation of previously mined areas. That makes the payment of the Commonwealth for future mining equivalent to $2.70 per tonne with some 37 per cent of that being spent on the island's environment. The remainder would be available for capital works and other infrastructure upgrading on the island. The $2.70 per tonne is equivalent to about 6.5 per cent of the current phosphate price. That compares more than favourably with the 5 per cent, which was included in the Booth offer.

In negotiations with Elders it has also been agreed that the $2.70 will be indexed. The liquidator, my Department and the Attorney-General's Department have been negotiating leases and a contract of sale with Elders. Elders, in turn, have been negotiating with the union of Christmas Island workers on the workers' equity participation in the mine as well as on award conditions. I understand that negotiations between the Christmas Island workers and Elders have been proceeding well. Our information is that those negotiations will very shortly be satisfactorily concluded.

The Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Holding, will be visiting the island to finalise some of these arrangements and to talk with Christmas Island workers. I think that process will occur within the next couple of weeks. When one takes into account not just the $1.70 per tonne but the extra dollar, then I think one would have to conclude that returns to the Commonwealth have been maximised. As I said in the Senate the other day in my answer to Senator Boswell's question, we saw no reason to regret the decision that Mr Yeomans had made some time ago. I have not changed my mind since I answered Senator Boswell's question a couple of days ago. I hope what I have just revealed does something to allay the honourable senator's fears in that respect.

The honourable senator also mentioned the Cocos (Keeling) Islands floating hotel proposal. I agree with the honourable senator that the future of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands will no doubt rest on tourism. We need to ensure that we do all we can to bring about more tourist activity there. Naturally enough, given the environment of the area and its relatively untouched state, we do need to be careful. I do not have a briefing on that issue with me at the moment. I have checked on this matter in the last couple of weeks, and my recollection was that the Commonwealth has asked for some information of the developer of that floating hotel quite some months ago. Up until the last time I checked, we had not received a reply. We are still awaiting information from the developer before we proceed. From memory-I will check and get back to the honourable senator-I believe it is a matter of my making a decision on the environmental impact statement process and how far we want to go along that track. As I said, the Department has asked for more information from the developer before we make a final decision. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some comments about penalties as they relate to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. It is a good move to increase the penalties for sea dumping. However, I urge the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, to take a good look at an issue in my home State of Tasmania. As I understand it, the dumping of jarosite wastes off the edge of the Continental Shelf by the zinc works in Hobart is in violation of an international treaty. This has been going on for years. When I was a TDT television reporter in the mid-1970s, I did a number of stories on the dumping of this waste.

SPEECH.PARA: Vast quantities of jarosite, which contains cadmium, lead, zinc and mercury, is dumped south of Tasmania, ironically in the waters where the Japanese come to fish for tuna which they feel are free of pollution. In fact, these waters are presently being polluted with the very same types of minerals-for example, mercury-which caused so much danger in Minimata Bay, Japan. Yet this goes on day after day, year after year.

When I was in the State Parliament, a number of people came to me with statements that this material was not even being dumped as far off-shore as the Continental Shelf. It was being dumped closer in to Tasmanian waters. We were never able to prove this although a number of very expert people maintained that this was so. But the fact remains that the Anson is still dumping this jarosite waste off the coast. This is a very sensitive political problem in Tasmania because the zinc works is a major employer of people in the Hobart area. As we all know, Tasmania, until recently at least, has not paid much attention to any environmental pollution control laws. It has recently moved to clean up the Derwent River, but it has done nothing about the jarosite waste being dumped off the Tasmanian coast.

The fishermen and environmentalists are concerned. Greenpeace is so concerned that it may be forced to take direct action. I urge the Minister to take a good look at this matter because I am sure that, since it is in violation of an international treaty, the Federal Government could and should have an involvement. I draw this to the Minister's attention and urge him to take action, as I know he is interested in the well-being of the environment, to protect the Tasmanian fisheries and the Tasmanian environment generally by examining the operations of the jarosite dumping vessel, the Anson.
