TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to lead the debate for the Opposition on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. In doing so, I would like to explain some of the amendments that the Opposition intends to move. This omnibus Bill seeks to amend the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952, the Airports (Surface Traffic) Act 1960, the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act 1988, the Broadcasting Act 1942, the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 and the Telecommunications Act 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: The Air Navigation (Charges) Act provides for the payment of charges in respect of the use of aircraft at Commonwealth aerodromes or aerodromes for which financial assistance is provided by the Commonwealth. Most importantly, the Act also provides for the payment of penalties if charges are not paid within 28 days. The legislation seeks to repeal certain provisions in the Airports (Surface Traffic) Act 1960.

The Australian Centennial Roads Development Act provides for the funding for a program of financial assistance for land transport, in succession to earlier statutory schemes. My colleague Senator Lewis will speak on the changes to the Broadcasting Act 1942. It is proposed to amend section 89d of the Broadcasting Act, to remedy an oversight in the preparation of provisions in the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Act 1988. The Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 provides for the operation of the Federal interstate registration scheme.

It is proposed to amend the Telecommunications Act 1975 to allow Telecom to validate a number of routine zonal and telex charges which have been inadvertently implemented without by-law authorisation. These charges will be implemented retrospectively. It really is a hotchpotch of a Bill. The Government has brought forward the legislation in this format obviously with a view to saving precious time. But I intend to take my full time in bringing forward to the Senate one or two matters. I want to refer particularly to road funding.

It is certainly our intention to bring forward a number of key amendments which we believe correct anomalies in the Bill. Essentially, these amendments relate to the provision of more than the current 4.95c per litre excise duty on fuel that is put towards road funding. They seek to make changes in respect of aviation because we quite rightly believe that the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority should be required to operate with the same standard of efficiency and cost minimisation that they expect of the public. They also address the hypocrisy of this Government in bringing forward retrospective legislation to cover up for a bureaucratic error.

I believe it is appropriate for us to consider the deplorable situation which exists within the Australian road network. On only Monday of this week I heard one of the most astonishing statements I have ever heard in my short time here. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, stated:
I think that anyone who is reasonably familiar with roads around Australia would know that the condition of the roads has never been better than it is now.

This statement will surely go down as one of the most ridiculous statements ever made by a Minister in this place. I place on record a challenge to Senator Walsh to get in his chauffeur-driven limousine and drive around some of the rural areas of Australia. If he does, he will hear a resounding cry from those who are sick and tired of putting up with substandard roads. He will hear, as I have heard on my travels around Australia from time to time, particularly from local governments, that they are sick and tired of these roads.

The Municipal Association of Victoria recently spent quite considerable amounts of money on finding out what the situation of its road system is. It is shocking to have to report that some of the councils in the north-east of Victoria are considering pulling up their sealed roads because they cannot afford to maintain them. The condition of our road network is a national disgrace and any government which allows matters to deteriorate to the present level should hang its head in shame. I have no doubt that, during the debate on this Bill, we will be hearing a lot of huffing and puffing from Government senators on the merits of their road policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are yawning, actually.
—There is the first reaction from the Minister.
—It is one of his more intelligent reactions.

—He is obviously still getting over yesterday's problems. There is one fact which cannot be denied: today, under this Labor Government, road funding stands at $1.215 billion and, when the Labor Government came to office in 1983, the figure stood at $1.250 billion. The reality is evident. In real dollar terms, the level of road funding has been deteriorating to the tune of 30 to 40 per cent and, in actual dollar terms, has dropped by approximately $450m in six years.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I came to this place I was involved in local government in Tasmania, as some honourable senators will know. I am fortunate to have contacts in local government around Australia. As I said previously, from talking to those bodies, particularly the Australian local government associations, it has become very clear to me that there is intense dissatisfaction with the present situation. The fact is-and a lot of people do not realise this-that local governments are now spending at least $100m a year more than State governments and $300m more than the Federal Government on their road systems.

If anyone wants further evidence of the feeling in the community about roads, one only has to hear what the nation's motoring organisations are saying. The New South Wales motoring body, the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA), recently completed a report on road safety statistics. The results are alarming, to say the least. The NRMA's research through its Traffic and Safety Department has produced statistics which show that Australia has 2.1 fatalities per 100 million vehicle kilometres travelled compared with 1.5 in the United States of America, 1.7 in Sweden and 1.9 in Great Britain. These results prove that Australian roads are perhaps the most dangerous in the world to travel on; the correlation between road safety and road condition is self-evident.

The other resounding message that has been coming through from the motoring organisations is that road funding cut-backs are likely to cost 7,000 lives by the year 2000. This represents 600 people a year between now and the year 2000, and does not even take into account the massive social cost to the community of such unnecessary suffering. I heard Senator Collins say yesterday that in all his time as a member of the St John's Ambulance, waiting on accidents in the Northern Territory, he did not see any evidence of bad roads causing accidents. That may be the case. I do not disbelieve him, but I do not feel that Senator Collins would be getting underneath cars and finding out whether they had broken shock absorbers or tie rod ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins could not fit under a car, unless it was a very large truck on a hoist.
—Right. We must take notice of motoring organisations which have better expertise than perhaps Senator Collins has on the effect of roads on cars.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will also be aware that the Automobile Association of Australia (AAA) has become so concerned about the matter that it has mounted a very high profile campaign. The theme of the campaign is: `Where are the roads that our petrol taxes pay for?'. That is a very apt question in this debate. It speaks for itself. It suggests that the people of Australia, particularly the motorists, are fed up with the situation, particularly over the last six years. This was highlighted by Mr Fred Watt who recently handed over the reins of the Automobile Association of Australia following three years of very distinguished service as its president. He had this to say in his annual address for 1988:

Clearly motorists deserve a far better road system in return for the enormous revenue collected from them by the Federal Government through the petrol pump. There is much more at stake, however, than obtaining a fairer deal for motorists.

Sub-standard roads are a prominent factor in many crashes. Hazards such as narrow lanes, slippery and broken surfaces, roadside trees and poles, sharp curves, blind corners, soft shoulders and poor signposting contribute to an estimated 30 per cent of all crashes.

Badly designed and inadequately maintained roads add considerably to vehicle operating costs. Rough surfaces, for example, can increase repair costs by up to 36 per cent and fuel consumption by up to 20 per cent.

Traffic congestion in our major cities is so bad that most motorists spend as much as a third of their time during peak periods standing still. As well as being extremely frustrating, this type of stop/start driving wastes more petrol, imposes extra wear and tear on vehicles and adds to pollution in our cities.
Mr Watt had further comments to make regarding the overall effect of the Automobile Association's campaign. He said:

However, it is not only motorists who stand to gain from improving our roads. This would provide substantial benefits to the entire community as a result of fewer crashes, lower transport costs and greater employment opportunities just to name a few.

Mr Acting Deputy President, over the years in which the Hawke Labor Government has been in power, most motorists have wasted two weeks of their lives sitting in traffic jams. It is obvious to all concerned that road usage is increasing. By the year 2000, we can expect the number of cars on our roads to go up by approximately 30 per cent and road freight by approximately 60 per cent. One cannot help but wonder what these motorists will face unless there is a drastic turn-round in the present situation.

An Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey conducted in 1985 predicted there would be continuing growth in road transport. It found that road transport contributed about $5.4 billion per year of Australia's gross domestic product. Between 1982 and 1985, the cargo hauled on Australia's roads increased by 25 per cent and it is expected that road freight will double by the year 2000. A very significant point in this debate is that the generally accepted life span of roads is around 20 years. More than half of our roads in Australia have now reached that age. One can only ask the question: Who will maintain them and how can the problems be alleviated?
I return to Senator Walsh's comment on Monday when he said:
I think that anyone who is reasonably familiar with roads around Australia would know that the condition of the roads has never been better than it is now.
All I can say is that Senator Walsh certainly is not familiar with the roads around Australia and obviously a few of his colleagues are not either.

If one wanted further evidence of the significance of the conditions of the roads on lives, one only has to listen to what Government Ministers themselves have been saying. One Minister stated that one life a year was saved for each $4m spent on the road building effort. Since this Government came to power, it has cut road funding by approximately $450m. Taking that analysis further, the lack of funding could be said to have cost 110 lives since this Government came to power.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Minister said that?
—Mr Peter Morris.
—Could you give us that again?

—He stated that one life a year was saved for each $4m spent on improving the road building effort. Since this Government has been in power funding has been cut by at least $450m. Taking that statement further, one finds that the lack of funding could be said to have cost 110 lives since this Government came to power.
—That is disgraceful-absolutely disgraceful!

—I have received many letters in my office and, no doubt, others have, too. One letter I received was from four very knowledgeable signatories-Professor Peter Scott, the President of the AAA, Mr John Burton, the president of the Australian Bus and Coach Association, Mr Bruce McIver, President of the Australian Livestock Transporters Association, and Mr Peter Rocke, President of the Australian Road Transport Federation. I quote from that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of road funding is becoming increasingly critical to Australia as the consequences of the current Government's cutbacks are becoming more and more apparent. These consequences do not show up in the short term but rather accrue progressively as a result of lower maintenance standards and an inability to increase the capacity of the road system to meet increasing demand. They ultimately produce higher vehicle operating costs, less efficient industries and more road deaths and injuries.
So those people, too, believe the claims that are being made by the automobile associations.

It is in this climate that we are bringing forward an amendment to the Bill on behalf of the coalition, which seeks to ensure that the Government reverses its current trend of cutting road funding, recognises the significance of the problem and returns to the Australian people a better deal than the lousy 4.95c per litre which is presently being spent on roads. Even in 1988 the Government returned 5.66c per litre. So, 22.39c per litre is being thieved from motorists at the petrol pumps, and of the 4.95c being returned, local government, which spends the most on roads, is receiving only one cent per litre.

It might also be of interest to honourable senators that it is not only the road users who are being forced to pay these crippling taxes. The projected income from petroleum products excise in 1988-89 is $5.05 billion. In addition to that, the projected income from crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) excise for the same year is something like $1.383 billion-giving a total projected petroleum excise figure for 1988-89 of $6.4 billion. Currently, each one cent excise on motor spirit and non-exempt diesel fuel combined is worth about $230m to the Hawke Government in a full year. I am sure it will be agreed that this situation is motivated simply by greed. Certainly it is causing disquiet in several other sectors of industry, particularly in maritime circles. Why the hell should people who are in fishing or shipping, or are involved in the manufacture of pleasure boats, have to contribute heaps of money? They do not use our roads.

I can give a good example. Just recently I made representations on behalf of the Tasmanian Ferry Company, which is going to introduce a very innovative shipping service across Bass Strait, using a wave-piercing catamaran manufactured by Bob Clifford down in Hobart. It has applied to the Government to waive the excise on diesel fuel because it would add $26 to the price of a return trip. The company is paying navigation and wharfage charges; why should it have to pay the excise on diesel fuel? It is not using our roads. The same principle applies to airlines. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, took the excise off aviation fuel because the airlines were not using the roads. The same principle applies to those who are using our waterways. I know that when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was in Hobart he visited Mr Clifford's new yard and made some overtures, but I am not aware of any government commitment in that matter.

Another factor which is often overlooked in the road funding rip-off, when considering the value of road funding, is the important multiplier effect. It is estimated that for every $1m spent on roads, about 60 jobs are created. With every $100m spent on roads, unemployment benefits could drop by $38m. The Federal and State governments could also expect to collect something like $16m in extra taxes. This means that for every $100m spent on roads, the net cost to the Government is only $46m. This, of course, does not take into account the advantages that flow to all road users from having improved road networks.

We cannot get away from the situation that one of the principal problems which we have with the taxing arrangements for road funding is that the Hawke Labor Government has chosen to index the excise on petroleum for the first time. This means that the tax is now increasing every six months in line with inflation. With inflation running at a rampant rate, the excise on diesel and petrol, as well as the excise on avgas, has gone up by about one cent in the past six months. At a time when more and more Australians are using our road system, and when the amount of goods being transported is increasing, the proportion of the amount of revenue collected from road users which is being returned to them is less and less. As a result, the amount of money now being spent on roads is decreasing. The money simply goes into Consolidated Revenue, and a fixed rate proportion is taken out. There is no doubt that a better roads system would allow us more adequately to supply the exports that we so badly need to get our balance of trade back into line. This is not just my view. I cite the Government's own Economic Planning Advisory Council, which recently reported that the industry reforms had the potential to take $2 billion a year from Australia's transport bill, boosting gross domestic product by 1.6 per cent.

The other important factor that we need to consider is the effect of road funding on the efficiency of industry. By that I refer particularly to our primary manufacturing and resource industries. These resource industries are subject to massive costs in the transportation area. We know that much of the transport is by rail, but when we look at our rural areas-the country centres which are the lifeblood of our nation, particularly in recent times-we see that any hope of decentralisation will remain slim until Government is prepared to provide industry with a means of transporting these goods quickly and efficiently between centres.

Over the past six years, the road users have witnessed this Government treating them with contempt. For too long it has been clear that local councils, State governments and users alike are ready to revolt. I know that that is a strong word, but one has only to look at the reactions of all road users throughout the community to realise that the old saying that there are no votes in roads will be reversed at the next Federal election. Some honourable senators may remember the fateful words of the present Treasurer who in opposition proudly proclaimed that every petrol pump was an office for the Australian Taxation Office. By God, is that not true? The Treasurer has really used the petrol pumps to bleed as much as he can out of every motorist in Australia. He has mastered the art of exploitation so far as the Australian road users are concerned. In the simplest possible terms, he has slashed the relativity that used to exist between what was spent and what was collected from road users-from the 66 per cent of excise that was spent on roads in 1983-84 to a measly 23 per cent today. In 1988, the Labor Government spent 5.66c per litre on roads. In 1989, despite the latest jump in the tax rate, we find that it is spending only 4.95c per litre-a cut of $33m. For most of us petrol is not a luxury-it is a necessity. Yet petrol, which is regarded by many industries as a lifeblood, is effectively taxed at a rate of 120 per cent, while luxuries, such as gold, jewellery and diamonds, are taxed at only 30 per cent. Federal Government fuel taxes currently represent about $6.5 billion a year. In contrast, under the Australian centennial roads development (ACRD) legislation expenditure will be only $1.215 billion.

The Treasurer has used a particular formula to bring down the amount that is being paid to governments. The ACRD payments are now indexed by the implicit price deflator, fuel being a non-farm product. It would not come as any surprise to honourable senators present to learn that over the last three years the amount indexed by the implicit price deflator formula has increased by only 8 per cent compared to the (CPI) increase. So it is obvious how we have arrived at this situation on road funding.

The Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill has, if nothing else, clearly placed on the record the Government's commitment to our roads. How can road users be expected to have any confidence in a government which gives the Minister and the Treasurer such scope to manipulate the level of road funding to suit its own ends?

In the brief time remaining to me I draw attention to the first part of the Bill, which deals with the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Civil Aviation Authority. I think it is fair to say that there is considerable concern around Australia about the operation of the Federal Airports Corporation-so much so that, after 18 months of operation, an inquiry is being held into the FAC and the Civil Aviation Authority. The Bill that we are debating is really only stating that charges should be paid to the Government within 28 days, whereas previously it was 45 days. The Government is practising double standards. Some of our pharmacists, who are supposedly receiving their payments from the Government within 30 days, are having trouble getting money out of the Government mostly within 50 or 60 days. The delays are sending a lot of them to the wall. Yet here the Government is penalising those airfield people after 28 days. We will be moving an amendment which we hope will close off that anomaly and revert to the old 45 days, which is only right and fair. The Government does not have the right to impose a standard such as this when it cannot adhere to those sorts of standards itself.

In closing, I refer briefly to comments made by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, Mr Bob Brown, in which he sought to cast doubts on our statements about road funding. We said that the Federal Government allocates just 20 per cent of the fuel tax it collects from motorists to roads. Mr Brown and the Government would have us believe that a much greater share is returned to State and local governments for roads. Mr Brown has claimed that these fuel taxes also help the Federal Government to provide untied grants to States and local councils to assist their road programs. Mr Brown has failed to point out-and I am sure that he is acutely aware of this-that that is true only to the extent that the amount of fuel tax that is not allocated to roads is paid into Consolidated Revenue, from which those grants are provided. These grants are untied and may be used for any purpose. The Minister's claim that those grants are spent on roads is a further attempt to dupe the public. They are not necessarily spent on roads at all. We have only to look at the urban transport situation in Sydney, and there are plenty of other examples around Australia of where that is not happening.

The Government, in touting its claims of massive road funding, has conveniently forgotten that it was a previous coalition government that established the Australian bicentennial road development program and that was funded purely by motorists through a levy of 2c a litre on fuel. That money was all returned to roads. Recently we have witnessed a phenomenon which I believe is indicative of the way in which the road debate is heading. In a massive show of dissatisfaction, local councils in the western suburbs of Sydney intend to block the release of home sites until the Federal Government contributes more funding to roads. I suggest that, by doing this, those people in the western suburbs, like the rest of us, are suggesting that they have had enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 which is before us is quite a comprehensive Bill. Most of the items contained in it have been before us previously in one form or another and I will not elaborate on them. I simply say that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Bill, and I would like to make some basic observations about transport.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats' position is that we ought to take a good hard look at our transportation system and its impact upon our way of life, our environment and our financial situation. Logic would dictate that since most of the population of Australia is concentrated in coastal cities, most goods should be moved by sea between these coastal cities, as was the case when the country was established. The use of ships is environmentally sound. There is no problem with road beds or the maintenance of right of way. Ships can carry large loads with relatively low fuel costs. The waterfront is being reformed. The crewing problems are being resolved. Ships are a viable form of transport which should be encouraged at all times. If, for some reason or another, bulk goods cannot be shipped by sea, the next preferable option should be rail.

Over the last few decades rail has come into some disfavour. Of course, it was once hailed as the great breakthrough in land transport. Railroads sprang up all over the world and served well to carry goods and passengers between areas. But now roads have captured the political imagination and roads get the funding. But rail is still a very logical way to carry goods and passengers. In fact, it is so logical that we see a resurgence in rail with the very fast train projects and the development of new road beds around the world.

The highways themselves are being misused mightily by the transport companies that move goods around the country. The trucks, which are increasingly taking over our highways, do not pay their own way; they are subsidised heavily by the taxpayer. They are a double disadvantage for the taxpayer. Firstly, they are a hazard on the roads as there are numerous and increasing accidents between trucks and cars; and secondly, they break the roads down; they actually degrade the roads. In my home state of Tasmania the woodchip trucks are continually being mentioned as the chief hazard to the roads. Unfortunately, the councils which are forced to maintain the roads simply do not get enough in revenue to make up for the damage the trucks cause.

This is an ironical situation. While the trucks do not pay their way-and the taxpayers of the country are expected to support and subsidise them; in fact, they subsidise all of the transportation system in one way or another-we find that there is full cost recovery in aviation. I have always been interested in finding out-perhaps Senator Gareth Evans can explain this to me when he gets to his feet-why aviation has been singled out as the one service performed in this country which must have full cost recovery. We do not ask the police to have full cost recovery, and our sewerage system does not have full cost recovery. Why should an essential transportation system such as aviation be subject to full cost recovery? I do not see why. Perhaps there is some latent image in the minds of some politicians that only the wealthy can fly or only the wealthy will benefit from aviation, and therefore it should be taxed heavily and made to pay its own way. But in fact, in our modern society, everyone in this country benefits from aviation. Goods are moved by air and passengers travel. It is not something for the wealthy; it is very much part of our basic transportation structure.

We are specifically talking about air navigation charges and landing charges. The previous speaker, Senator Calvert, referred to a Senate examination of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). Yes, we are looking at the FAC and the CAA. We received hundreds of submissions about the lack of equity in the system of charging. We heard from a flight operator at Coolangatta airport who takes people for sightseeing tours around the area. Every time he lands and takes off his aeroplane he is forced to pay. A viable commercial operation has been turned into a nightmare. He is up for thousands and thousands of dollars per year simply because he operates a service that takes people up in the air and lands them every 10 minutes or so. He has to pay through the nose. He is not causing any particular damage to the runway. It is just that the Government says, `Here is a guy who we can get some dough off; let's go for it'. This goes on throughout the system. There is a basic attitude, `These are wealthy people; they can pay'. They are not wealthy.

With these high charges for aviation, the Government is actually jeopardising the future not only of general aviation but also of the airline industry. Who will train the pilots when the instructors can no longer afford to operate at our airports? Who will train the pilots for the airliners of the future? It is not just rich doctors and lawyers who own their own aeroplanes who will be suffering; the whole country will suffer. I am a former flight instructor and I know that the margins are very slim in a commercial venture such as this. There is not a lot of money to be made. At least 50 per cent of the people in general aviation and in the flight instructing area are there because they love aviation. They want to make it succeed. They love flying. But this Government is making it more and more difficult for them to stay in business.

I notice that the Opposition proposes to move an amendment. Opposition senators did not talk to me about their amendment. I have had no contact at all from them. I see that they wish to extend the 28-day payment period to 45 days. Government senators did seek me out to explain their position. They have stated that to extend this time payment period would raise costs and cause bureaucratic difficulties between the FAC, the CAA and the Department of Transport and Communications in the collection of the fees. I certainly do not want to increase the number of bureaucratic person-hours involved in collecting charges because that will increase the cost to aviation.

As I say, I have not had any contact with the Opposition. I do not know its reasoning. General aviation will not be involved with this. As I understand it, this is not for avgas-it has nothing to do with flight training and that sort of thing; it is for avtur. If it has any impact at all it will impact on Sir Peter Abeles and Australian Airlines. Frankly, I think they can take care of themselves. I have taken the Government's information on board and it sounds logical. Because this will not affect general aviation, which I feel needs to be protected, the Australian Democrats will not be voting for the amendment to be moved by the Opposition in the Committee of the Whole.

I will conclude my remarks. I restate that the Australian Democrats will be supporting these Bills but we wish that the Government would spend some time on advance planning and the development of a philosophy that will put all forms of transport-ships, rail, road and aircraft-on an equal basis and endeavour to put in place a transportation system that is environmentally sound and also serves the people of this country far better than the present systems are doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be addressing myself to two parts of the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 which the Senate is currently debating. I shall be dealing with part 5, which relates to amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942, and part 7, which deals with amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942 purport to correct an oversight in the scheme for limited licences, which was introduced by the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Act 1988. It is claimed that the provisions will enable the grant of limited broadcasting licences which involve transmissions from transponders on an Aussat satellite. Limited licences allow streamlined licensing of a range of broadcasting services which, because of restrictions on duration, purpose, content or other aspects, do not raise the same public interest concerns as conventional broadcasting licences. For example, teletext services will be authorised under limited licences. The provisions in this Bill will allow existing remote commercial television service licensees to seek limited licences to broadcast teletext services to remote area homesteads which have satellite receivers. It will also allow licensing, if and when appropriate, of other limited broadcasting services by satellite to remote homesteads. The coalition parties will not be opposing this part of the Bill.

I wish to raise with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans)-I will be doing so in detail during the committee stage of the Bill-what I believe to be a drafting error. I wonder whether anyone in the Department of Transport and Communications or in the office of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) ever reads the legislation to see what it actually says. The Government, Ministers and departmental officers ought to realise that the legislation means what it says; not what the Ministers or the departmental officers want it to mean.

This Bill amends the Broadcasting Act 1942. We last dealt with that in Bill No. 146 of 1988-the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. I do not know whether the Government meant it but it has not been corrected. The Government has remained silent on the matter. At the time, I pointed out that that legislation, by a back door method, allowed the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) to have sponsorship broadcast-in other words, advertisements by way of sponsorship-on its channels. There was also a means by which the amendments to the legislation could have enabled, and can still enable, the ABC to have advertisements on its programs. At the time the Government had not told the ABC that as a result of the legislation that would be the case. Clearly, the Government did not realise that that was the purpose of some of the amendments.

I now draw attention to what is being proposed in this legislation. In Bill No. 146 of 1988 we had two schedules of amendments. In schedule 3 we dealt with paragraph 89d (3) (a). That amendment to the Bill inserted `limited licence' after `public licence'. It is almost unbelievable, but in schedule 4 of the same Bill there was another reference to the same paragraph. It said:
Omit `, limited licence or re-transmission', substitute `or limited'.

That complex arrangement meant that the words `limited licence' were inserted by schedule 3 and the words `limited licence or re-transmission' were deleted by schedule 4. That seems to me to be an extremely clever piece of legislation for the Parliament to have passed. What was then substituted in schedule 4 were the words `or limited'. It is my view that the consequence of those proposals is that the Act will now read, in paragraph 89d (3) (a), `in the case of a licence other than a remote licence, public licence or limited licence-authorises the operation, in accordance with the warrant and by a person or persons specified in the warrant'. By that complex set of amendments in schedule 3 and schedule 4 of Act No. 146 of 1988, the words `limited licence' were inserted. When we look at this Bill before us today we see that subclause 12 (a) inserts in paragraph (3) (a) of section 89d `a limited licence' after the words `a public licence'. I say to the Minister that in my view-and I would appreciate some advice as to whether it is right-that amendment is totally unnecessary because the words proposed to be inserted were in fact inserted when we dealt with this legislation, I think, in December of last year. I will raise that again in due course during the committee stage of the Bill. I mention it now to enable the Minister's officers to apply their minds to whether or not that is correct.

I turn now to the amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1975, which is part 7 of this Bill. The amendments in this part propose to validate retrospectively charging arrangements undertaken by Telecom Australia for which currently it does not have by-law coverage. In other words, Telecom is making charging arrangements which it has no legal right to make. The Minister in his second reading speech acknowledged the errors which `generally reflect inadequate administrative controls and inappropriate reporting procedures within Telecom's organisation'. In other words, the Minister is slating Telecom for its inadequate administrative controls and inadequate reporting procedures within its organisation. As at September of last year there were 1,997 telephone charging zones and 5,227 telephone exchanges in the Commonwealth. In some cases as new exchanges have been opened network changes have been made in advance of by-law operation. In other words, Telecom changed the network, changed the charging arrangements, but did not have any legal right to make the changes. The network changes affected charging. Some were increased; some were reduced. But these altered charges were not authorised in advance by the by-laws and have still not been authorised-and will not be until the passage of this legislation.

Telecom claims that it is impossible to determine the net effect of the errors on individual customers. The effect would depend on the individual customer's calling pattern. The existing arrangements for which validation is proposed to be provided would have resulted in higher charges for calls in particular directions and lower charges for calls in other directions. The point is that when a network is relocated, if people have a normal pattern of calling some of their calls result in higher charges and some result in lower charges. However, it may very well be that there are people out there in the community who perhaps make calls in the one direction all the time. I could imagine some elderly people who perhaps never ring anyone other than their daughters or sons, daughters-in-law, or some member of their family. If those people were able to establish that, in my mind they would be able to establish satisfactorily that Telecom has increased, or maybe reduced, their charges as a result of its change to the network. It is possible that there are people out there who, as a result of the passage of this legislation, will retrospectively lose their right to claim from Telecom a refund of charges which Telecom was not authorised to make.

I appreciate it is unlikely that Telecom or individual customers possess the detailed records or information to enable accounts to be recalculated retrospectively if the amendments are not passed but it may very well be that there are people who are able to do it. It is proposed in this legislation to give Telecom protection from attempts by customers to challenge prior accounts on the basis of the legality of the zonal and other charging arrangements. Once again Telecom's actions are being given legislative protection. Telecom is the largest business operating in Australia. It is larger than the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, larger than the Coles-Myer group. Its revenues and expenditure are larger than the amount of money the Government of this country spends on the defence budget. Yet this poor body desperately needs the protection of Parliament to cover up for the mistakes it has made.

Let me assure the Senate that the Liberal and National parties will not be authorising Telecom to make retrospective charges or to correct retrospectively its charging arrangements by passing part 7 of this Bill. We will be voting against it during the committee stage. Under the existing charging arrangements if someone is able to establish a claim against Telecom, Telecom may have to suffer that and may have to refund moneys to customers. Telecom's ineptitude in this regard totally ignores the legislation. Telecom does not worry about its responsibility to the Parliament or to the people. It says, `Let's get the networks running and worry about the legality of our charging arrangements afterwards'.

Even now, as I understand, when Telecom became aware of this it could have immediately made by-laws which prospectively would have rectified the problems as they exist at the present moment. I gather that Telecom has chosen not to do that but to say, `Oh, well, we'll let the Parliament fix that up. We'll wait until the Parliament has passed this piece of legislation and then that will validate both retrospectively and prospectively our charging arrangements'. As far as the coalition parties are concerned, Telecom is just going to have to wear the fact that the legislation will not be passed by us and that it may have to make refunds to some of its customers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be referring, in the debate on this portfolio Bill, the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, to just three of the Acts which are being amended. The first one which I refer to is the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act 1988. The amendment which is being made in part 4 of the Bill is to the effect that a determination which is to be made with regard to funding under this Bill is to be treated as a regulation for the purposes of tabling and disallowance in this place. This is as a result of debate and discussions which took place when this Act was passed very late in the session last year-almost by way of a Christmas Eve exercise, on 21 December. It was a matter of great concern to the Australian Democrats and also to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that these determinations were to be made but were not to come before the Parliament for possible disallowance.

SPEECH.PARA: In his second reading speech the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) referred to the fact that this amendment comes before us by way of honouring an undertaking given by Senator Gareth Evans on 21 December. That undertaking was given to the Democrats when we expressed concern that the rate being set by the Minister should come under parliamentary scrutiny and be subject to disallowance. We welcome this amendment. I reiterate the comments made by my colleague Senator Sanders in this debate. He expressed some criticism of the Government's transport policy in general. I urge that a broader policy serving the community better, across a range of transport facilities and options, be implemented by this Government.

At the time of the passage of the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill we moved a second reading amendment in which we expressed our concern-a concern which has already been expressed by Senator Calvert-about the level of funding for roads specifically and urged that the Government take action in that area. We also called for a direct allocation-at the time we suggested one per cent of fuel excise-to fund the development of alternative renewable liquid fuels, especially ethanol, in order to reduce the adverse environmental impact of the use of non-renewable oil based fuels. This is another way in which we believe we can address the environmental and social impacts of the development of transport, in particular road transport, in this country. It is a challenging issue and one which certainly must be taken on board. I think public pressure will increase the need for alternatives in this area as the public becomes aware of the increasing damage to our environment by the use of non-renewable liquid fuels. That is not to say that we do not need roads and that we do not need road transport; it is simply to say that we do not believe there is a balance.

I am very interested that Senator Calvert has once again made impassioned pleas. I find it interesting that the Opposition seems to be very concerned about the state of the roads in this country. I am sure it is a genuine concern, but it is a very blinkered concern, coming from a political party which last night enabled legislation to be passed in the other place-and will enable it to be passed in this place-which will deregulate the wheat industry and the transport component of that industry and throw more traffic onto our roads, to the detriment of the rail system in our country. It will work against the very points which have been constantly made by Senator Calvert and others on that side of the House. It strikes the Democrats as extraordinary that we do not have support from the Opposition for the pressure which we wish to put on the development, for instance, of rail transport in this country, particularly to rural communities, which would give such communities more of a choice. I think Opposition members need to reflect on their policies of privatisation which lead to some of these almost unbelievable conflicts between what they say on one piece of legislation and what they do on another piece of legislation.

In regard to the amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942, the Opposition needs to look closely at its ideological position on privatisation and the impact this will have on people in isolated areas. the President of the Gunning Shire-

said local people, on behalf of all highway users, demand four solutions: a reduction of the truck speed limit to 80 km/h on single-carriageway roads; more effective policing, especially at night; an immediate start to the long-promised bypass of the area; and the upgrading of the southern rail line to take freight off the roads.

What justification does this Government have for moving away not only from the Fraser Government's program but also from its own? What excuse does it have to present to this chamber for diverting the money to that nice strip of concrete on the western side of Lake Macquarie? Of course there were dangerous sections of the Newcastle freeway. That is why it was vital that the major bridge at Mooney Mooney be built. But the section on which so much money has been spent in recent years goes far past the turn-off which veers right to Newcastle. The improved road veers left around Lake Macquarie and leads towards Cessnock. Is anyone in this Government trying to pretend that that road carries anything like the traffic that the Hume Highway carries? What is even more disgusting about this is that this Government is praising itself, patting itself on the back, for announcing that we will get these bypasses, the dual carriageways, the four lanes by 1993.

Apparently, we are supposed to beat drums and cheer because this Government will delay for five years doing what it promised to do by 1988. It is incredible hide for yet another Newcastle-based Minister to tell the people who use the Hume Highway that at last Goulburn, Yass and Mittagong will be bypassed and the Cullerin Range deviation will be constructed by the end of 1993-94. In fact, I overstated the completion date. It is not 1993, it is the 1993-94 financial year. Work is expected to have finished on the Mittagong, Goulburn and Yass bypasses and on the Cullerin Range deviation by that time. At the moment this is an incredibly dangerous highway. The Government is announcing yet again projects that were announced in 1982, projects which were supposed to have been completed by 1988. The Minister and the Government are announcing them again as some dramatic and magnificent step forward. What incredible hide, what gall, what a bunch of phonies, what total lack of integrity to try this kind of stunt on people who are seeing the consequences of this Government's diverting road funds for its own pork-barrelling and also reducing the funds. No government can stand more condemned on the question of integrity than this Government on this matter.

As the honourable member for Richmond, Mr Blunt, said in the other place, the recent announcement of a five-year strategy for national highways and arterials is the third time that this same roads program has been announced. The dollar figures might look a bit bigger but, had the work been done when it was supposed to have been done, the dollar figures would have been smaller because inflation, which continues under this Government at a faster rate than in other countries, eats into the money available and adds to the cost of each project. As I said earlier in my speech, it is evident from the Minister's latest statement that it will not be completed until 1993 or 1994. That is why when I was the local member in 1982 the Fraser Government's Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, agreed to have the total bypass of both Mittagong and Berrima completed by the 1988 Bicentennial.

Giving this number one priority to the Hume Highway, which also covered the Cullerin Range and Jugiong deviations, was considered essential at the time because of the huge traffic flow and the accident rate. This was reinforced to the Minister when he got caught in a two-hour traffic jam south of Mittagong with me one day. He has been unable to stop this Government's marauding financial incursions on the Hume Highway, which has led to a massive increase in risks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs inform the Senate of measures being taken by the Government to improve the process for the recognition of overseas qualifications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 April this year my colleague Mr Dawkins and I announced a package of training reforms that will significantly improve the opportunities for migrants to have their skills recognised and provide fairer access to the labour market, education and training. They address the deficiencies in current arrangements which are fragmented and rely excessively on paper qualifications rather than assessment of competencies and skills causing, of course, personal stress and hardship and substantial economic loss to the economy. The major objectives of the reforms are to develop a fair and open system, to promote occupational deregulation, rationalise and simplify administrative process and provide better information, advice and personal support services. Key elements of the reform program are the establishing of a national office of overseas skills recognition in the employment, education and training portfolio; promoting consistent, national standards and competency based assessment; encouraging State initiatives, including State overseas qualifications units and better Commonwealth-State cooperative arrangements; developing a program that builds on unused and unrecognised skills by providing personal support services, such as better access to education and training for remedial and bridging courses; and administrative reforms to the machinery of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act are due to be announced shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: The national office of overseas skills recognition will provide a focus for the reform program. It subsumes and extends the role of the Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications, which had previously been in my portfolio. As a first step, funding for Jobtrain will increase from $55.4m in 1987-88 to $86.7m in 1988-89 providing opportunities for all Australians, including migrants, to receive vocational training. Additional funding has been set aside to provide places for bridging courses. The number of these bridging courses will rise to 180 in 1989-90 and to 200 in 1990-91.

In conclusion, our goal is to provide the opportunity for all Australians, whether trained in this country or overseas, to use their skills to full potential. There is no quick or easy solution. It requires cooperation from all governments, employers, unions, professional groups and individuals if we are to achieve genuine reform. I am confident that this package will create the framework for progressive changes to offer great benefits to migrants facing difficulties in getting their skills recognised, as well as making a major contribution to the structural adjustment in the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to the announcement in the April economic statement of a reduction of $31m this year, $96m next year and $156m the following year in outlays under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Is he aware that pharmacists have already suffered a reduction in income in the vicinity of 14 per cent since January 1988 as a direct result of changes already made to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and these latest changes will result in a further 5 per cent reduction in pharmacists' incomes? When the rest of the community can at least look forward to a wage increase later this year, why has the Government singled our pharmacists as one section of the community which will not only not get an increase in income, but also will suffer a real drop in income and the additional disadvantage of having their incomes frozen until the end of 1990 as a result of the Government's refusal to index the dispensing fee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Government reformed the pharmaceutical benefits scheme previously and in the April economic statement announced that it would continue with that reform. That reform is structured in a way in which the benefits to consumers of pharmaceuticals are protected. That point is often lost in the political debate from the Opposition ranks.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that the honourable senator says that pharmacists have suffered a 14 per cent reduction in income. I am not sure what the authority for that assertion is, but along with the other allegations in the honourable senator's question I will refer that to the Minister for Community Services and Health and give her an answer in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Minister seen overseas press reports that many hundreds of world jet airliners are now at between 75 per cent and 100 per cent of their economic design lives, or have even exceeded 100 per cent of design lives, at which point metal fatigue cracking could occur? Are any commercial jet airliners operated by Australia's domestic airlines or by Qantas Airways Ltd in these categories; that is over 15 years old? What information does the Government have on whether international airlines operating into Australia have aircraft in these categories? What actions does the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) take to check on ageing jet airliners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, the answer is yes. I am advised that there are about 1,300 transport aircraft in worldwide service which have exceeded the manufacturer's design life goal. However those goals were determined when the aircraft were designed as the desired life span. They do not indicate that the aircraft is unsafe after that period. Fatigue damage is progressive throughout the life of aircraft and a fail-safe structure such as used on these airliners can, if properly inspected, remain in service until economic factors determine replacement. As to the second question, whether any commercial jetliners in these 15-year-plus categories are operated by the Australian domestic airlines or by Qantas, the answer is yes. Qantas operates several Boeing 747 aircraft and Australian Airlines operates DC9 aircraft and a Boeing 727, all of which are in the region of the manufacturer's design goal. The Boeing 747 economic design life objective is 20,000 flights or 60,000 hours. World wide there are five and 68 aircraft respectively which have exceeded these aims. The greatest amount of work which Qantas aircraft have achieved, as at 20 April 1989, is 19,331 landings and 57,043 hours. It should be realised, however, that the economic design life is based on a judgment that beyond that life it would become less and less economically viable to maintain the aircraft concerned to ensure its continued safety and service. I emphasise that it does not mean that the aircraft would suddenly become unsafe. Rather, it would become more costly to make sure that it remained safe.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the third question about the information we have on whether international airlines operating into Australia have aircraft in these categories, the short answer is we do not have details of how many international airlines operating into Australia have aircraft in the ageing category. However, there is nothing to prevent such operations, as the aircraft have a valid certificate of airworthiness from their country of registration. On the final question, relating to the intentions of the CAA in this respect, the CAA is taking part in discussions with world airworthiness authorities and manufacturers. Appropriate action will be taken as recommendations are made. This action will take the form of airworthiness directives requiring inspections or modifications for fatigue and corrosion damage. The CAA is satisfied that Australian airline aircraft are not in any immediate danger through exceeding their design goal, but the position is being kept under close review. No checks are done on overseas aircraft. This is the responsibility of the country of registration and the associated airworthiness authority. The CAA is confident, nonetheless, that those countries operating aircraft into Australia are upholding their international commitments with respect to safety considerations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It relates to the pollution of the territorial sea around Australia. When control over the three-mile zone of the territorial sea was handed back to the States by the former coalition Government did the Commonwealth and States agree that the States would legislate to protect the sea from pollution? Failing the States doing that, did the Commonwealth and States agree that the Commonwealth would legislate to protect the sea from pollution even though the three-mile zone was otherwise controlled by the States? Have any or all of the States passed such protective legislation? Has the Commonwealth passed legislation, and if not why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an agreement reached, but it is not quite in the terms just put by Senator Coulter. At the time of the offshore constitutional settlement of 1979, agreement was reached in relation to ship based pollution, whereby the existing arrangements would continue so that Commonwealth legislation would apply to ships outside the territorial sea and State legislation would apply to all ships within the territorial sea.

ANSWER.PARA: The offshore constitutional settlement also included agreement that the Commonwealth should prepare legislation which would implement the provisions of the International Convention in Relation to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties and the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage. In implementing the latter convention, a saving clause was to be inserted to allow the States to legislate to implement certain aspects of the convention if they wished to do so. With regard to land based marine pollution and marine pollution through dumping, discussions between the Commonwealth and the States were to continue.

With regard to the second and third parts of Senator Coulter's question, specifically relating to ship based marine pollution, as a result of further consultation between the Commonwealth and the States, Commonwealth legislation now applies in the territorial sea but there is a roll-back clause which allows the States to legislate consistent with the relevant international conventions. Subsequent to the offshore constitutional settlement, the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 was enacted to protect the environment by regulating the dumping into the sea and the incineration at sea of wastes and other matter and the dumping into the sea of certain other objects and, as the legislation says, for related purposes.

The Act includes provisions that where the Minister is satisfied that State or Territory law will on and after a particular date make provision for giving effect to the Convention on the Protection of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter-that is, the London Dumping Convention-the Minister may disapply the said Act in favour of corresponding State or Territory legislation. Tasmania, South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia have passed legislation. Tasmania has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Commonwealth and the ministerial disapplication-I do not like that word much, nevertheless it is the one I am supposed to use-of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 with respect to the coastal waters of Tasmania is in effect.

With regard to land based marine pollution, a variety of State legislation is in effect but unfortunately no consistent regime yet exists. I am writing to my State ministerial colleagues on the Australian Environment Council to put to them that we ought to do more towards a national approach to water quality issues. I am hopeful that obvious and increasing public pressure will encourage the States to go along with the Commonwealth and perhaps set national water quality standards which will hopefully then mean that the awful problems we are experiencing in a number of places can at least be monitored against an appropriate and proper yardstick.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Do I correctly understand the Minister to be saying that the term `dumping at sea' refers not just to dumping from ships, as specified under the London Dumping Convention, but extends to the dumping at sea from land-based facilities? If so, does it apply, for instance, to the New South Wales situation with the dumping of large amounts of sewage at sea? Is that one of the situations to which he was referring in the latter part of his remarks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the question of sewage in Sydney and having an appropriate yardstick against which to measure that. Unfortunately, under the London Dumping Convention the Commonwealth has not been given power in respect of marine based pollution of the kind to which the honourable senators refers. Is that the answer which the honourable senator was requesting?
—If I may ask a further question, Mr President--
—Order! You have already had two questions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW CALEDONIA: ASSASSINATION OF JEAN-MARIE TJIBAOU

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the ramifications of last night's shocking assassination of Kanak leader, Jean-Marie Tjibaou, on a peaceful settlement for Australia's Pacific neighbour, New Caledonia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will now be all too sadly aware, the leader of the New Caledonian independence movement, the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front (FLNKS), Jean-Marie Tjibaou, was assassinated yesterday on the island of Ouvea, New Caledonia. His deputy, Yeweine Yeweine, died later from injuries sustained in the same attack. As I have already made clear in my response on the adjournment last night to tributes paid by you, Mr President, and by Senator Schacht and Senator Hill, both of whom were leading an Australian parliamentary delegation to New Caledonia just a couple of weeks ago, the Government deplores this shocking act of violence which has occurred at a time when hopes for a peaceful and lasting settlement in New Caledonia had begun to take root after years of unproductive violence and confrontation.

ANSWER.PARA: The French Government, in reacting to the deaths, has recalled the two men's political courage and responsibility and their role in helping to bring about reconciliation between the communities in New Caledonia. These sentiments are certainly fully endorsed by the Australian Government. Jean-Marie Tjibaou, whom I had the pleasure of meeting on several occasions in recent years, was a man of great capacity and great personal dignity. He was one of the central figures in the attempts over the last year to restore order and stability to New Caledonia. He played a crucial role in the negotiations which led to what have become known as the Matignon and Oudinot accords on the future of the Territory. He was a man of moderation, a man of peace, and one who was enormously respected in the region. His passing, and that of his deputy Yeweine, is a tragic matter. Again, I take this occasion, on behalf of the Australian Government and Parliament, to express the most sincere condolences possible to his family and people.

Details of the funerals have not yet been finalised, but present advice is that they will occur on Sunday. Subject to appropriate arrangements being put in place with the French authorities and the widows of the two men, it is the Government's intention that I, as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, represent Australia at the funerals. I hope it may also be possible for appropriate parliamentary representation to be arranged.

With respect to the implications of the deaths for the future of New Caledonia, the deaths constitute a major blow to the current attempts being made to bring about reconciliation among the communities in New Caledonia. Tjibaou and Yeweine represented the moderate mainstream leadership of the FLNKS which, after the tragedy of the Ouvea incident exactly a year ago, was prepared to recognise the futility of further confrontation and the profound necessity for reconciliation. Their passing will clearly leave a major vacuum in the leadership of the FLNKS, one which will not easily be filled. The traditional, consensual procedures of the FLNKS give cause for hope that there can be patience and understanding on the part of those involved within the FLNKS. I hope also that such moderation can be sustained across the full political spectrum in New Caledonia. The Australian Government simply hopes that the deaths of Tjibaou and Yeweine will do nothing to interrupt the processes now under way in New Caledonia and that Tjibaou's moderate spirit will continue to inspire the communities of that Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce a question about the business activities of government business enterprises. Is it the intention of the Government that government business enterprises engage only in the business activities for which they were established-plus incidental activities related to their basic function-or that they become active and perhaps even dominant players in all spheres of the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can provide Senator Lewis with an answer which would in any sense be satisfactory to him, because he has asked a very general question and there are a lot of interpretative difficulties about what the question means. I am not criticising the way he put the question. Australian Airlines, for example, operates in the tourist business which is an activity ancillary to its airline activity, but is not its full business. Telecom Australia operates an international subsidiary which does consulting work and has contracts in various countries to perform management and other functions. That was perhaps not intended years ago as a suitable activity for a telecommunications authority which is charged essentially with running the Australian telecommunications business, but it is a very sensible departure from the core business activity because telecommunications is increasingly international. The good technical standard in Telecom makes it very important for it to take advantage of export opportunities and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: I am trying to make the point that I could go through each of the authorities and make comments of that kind, which may nonetheless not lead to a satisfactory answer to the honourable senator's question. If Senator Lewis is asking me whether there is any general principle that government business enterprises should be confined to their core business activities as and when they were established, the answer is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the Minister's attempt to give me an answer. I choose one such enterprise, Australia Post, and ask whether it might go into a travel agency, for example. One could imagine that, as it has offices all around Australia. Would it be reasonable for it to buy a brewery, for example, which would see it indulging in activities totally different from those in which it has invested in the past? Could it raise funds for such activities by selling its post offices in Melbourne and Sydney? That is the sort of thing I have in mind. I ask Senator Button to address his mind to a point arising from his answer-and he may like to think about it: is it intended that these government business enterprises might be allowed to use the funds earned from the exercise of their monopoly powers in pursuit of business activities other than those core purposes for which they were established?

—Senator Lewis was kind enough to say that I may like to think about it, and I would. It is not that I regard it as a particularly difficult question; it is just that again things vary from one government business enterprise to another. For example, Telecom cross-subsidises in respect of various activities in which it is engaged and so on. All I can comment on at present is the example Senator Lewis gave about whether Australia Post could buy breweries. If I might be bold enough to make a comment, I think if it did it would be a disaster for Australian drinkers.

It has no idea of what the community is concerned about, which is why it has lost 20 per cent of the votes each by-election in the last 12 months, and why, in Merthyr, it will get creamed again. I hope that the Queensland Government starts to live up to its responsibilities and acts upon the long-standing Queensland National Park proposal to declare the Olive River gemfield a national park. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information on this. I ask the honourable senator to put the question on the Notice Paper.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What retrospective taxation legislation has been passed in the Senate? What retrospective taxation legislation has the Senate refused to pass? What inconsistencies are there in these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an excellent question which will provide an opportunity to put on the record some very important facts that ought to be more widely known than they are. Firstly, one should define what retrospectivity is in this context. There are very many examples under all sorts of governments of new taxation laws or amendments operating from the date of announcement, which may be some considerable time before the legislation comes into the Parliament. I can anticipate what Senator Stone is going to say.
—It is just that your Government has raised it to the level of an art form.

—Senator Stone would know very well that such retrospectivity happened under all sorts of governments. In this context I take retrospectivity to mean a law coming into operation prior to an announcement being made that such a law will be passed. There are two examples of this Parliament passing retrospective taxation legislation. The first was the Fraser Government's 1982 unpaid company taxation legislation. The second was the Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1988, a Government Bill, to which Senator Haines moved an amendment which was supported by all of the Australian Democrats and the Opposition. It imposed a retrospective capital gains tax liability on assets, the ownership of which had been rearranged between September 1985 and January 1987 pursuant to orders of the Family Court of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: There are many examples of the Senate rejecting Bills which imposed retrospective taxation liabilities. I will cite two. In 1984 a Labor Government introduced a Bill to reinsert section 3 (12) in the Fraser Government 1982 Act. That section was originally in the Fraser Government's Bill but was later pulled out by that Government. I could give the Senate the details of what that section did, but it would take some time and I will not bother to do it now. The Labor Party in Opposition in 1982 moved an amendment which was identical to the 1984 Bill later presented. That amendment was supported by two Democrat senators, by Senator Harradine and by the entire Labor Party Senate Caucus, but it was defeated. Also in 1984 a Bill was introduced to recoup the taxation avoided by employers who were running bogus superannuation schemes, commonly known as cherrypicker schemes.

The most notorious of the rogues who were operating these schemes were the Kelly brothers. For a period of between 10 and 15 years contributions which were deductable from the Kelly brothers taxable income were paid into a so-called superannuation fund. Of course, they were the trustees of the fund and controlled it. Ostensibly, the fund was for the benefit of their employees, although the employees were not aware of the existence of the fund. The Kelly brothers, being in charge of the fund, ensured that no employee ever qualified for the benefits under the trust deed of the fund, and sacked several employees immediately before they qualified for benefits. In other words, the fund was never used, and was never intended to be used, for the benefit of the employees-it was used for the benefit of the Kelly brothers at the expense of the rest of the taxpayers of Australia. We introduced a Bill in 1984 to recoup the tax that the Kelly brothers and others had evaded in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is a fascinating wander through a lot of history, but can I draw your attention to the very small number of questions currently being asked and the length of the Minister's reply. I ask you to ask him to bring his answer to a speedy conclusion.
—I am aware of the number of questions, but the answer is completely in order.
—That is absolutely correct, Mr President.
—I ask the Minister to take into account, however, the number of questions that are being asked in Question Time.

—I have been asked, in the third part of the question, about inconsistencies. I will cite two examples of inconsistency. In 1982 Senator Harradine voted for the then Labor Opposition's motion to reinsert the original clause 3 (12) of the Fraser Government's unpaid company tax legislation. In 1984 he voted against the Bill which had exactly that same provision in it. His vote in the first instance was not crucial to whether the amendment was carried; his vote in the second instance was crucial to whether the Bill was carried or defeated. It is not possible to be more inconsistent than to vote in opposite ways on the same question.

ANSWER.PARA: The second example I want to cite is that of Senator Haines. Prior to moving the retrospective amendment which she imposed on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) last year, Senator Haines had always voted against retrospective legislation ostensibly on the grounds of immutable principle, yet she moved that 1988 amendment which imposed a retrospective taxation liability.

She was told by me in the Senate at the time that it did have retrospective application, and it was explained to her why it had retrospective application. It is difficult to imagine anything much more inconsistent than a senator who knowingly allows rogues or crooks like the Kelly brothers to walk away with hundreds of thousands of dollars-I think it was about three-quarters of a million dollars that they filched from the taxpayers-and then moves an amendment imposing a retrospective liability on completely innocent people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

Can he confirm that the Government, in fact, did not approve the Wesley Vale pulp mill? Secondly, the last part of the press release says:

. . . the process to be adopted will have regard to the respective responsibilities of the Commonwealth/State Governments with the Commonwealth's role being confined to the impacts of effluents on the receiving environment.

Is that to be interpreted as meaning that the Commonwealth will confine its role solely to that particular matter and will not, for example, involve itself in assessments of the question of the resources to be provided for the operations of these pulp mills?

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the second part of the question, the resource issue is separate, and the answer is yes. So far as the first part of the question is concerned, there was an application to the Foreign Investment Review Board for investment by the company Noranda. Under the foreign investment legislation, the Commonwealth, in conjunction with legislation whose name temporarily eludes me-it comes under Senator Richardson's Department-has to approve, on environmental grounds, amongst other grounds, any investment taking place. It was that that was not approved.

—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has said that the resource issue is a separate issue and that the answer to the second part of my question is yes-namely, that the Commonwealth's role would be confined entirely to the impact of effluents on the receiving environment. Can he clarify whether that is a statement regarding simply the responsibility of his Department-the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-or whether it goes to the whole of the Commonwealth Government?

—In regard to the second part of the question, what I said was that there are different issues. In the case of Wesley Vale, I do not think that, at the stage it had got to, the Commonwealth was concerned with the resource issue so much as with the environmental impact of the mill.
—I am talking about your commitment to the Commonwealth's future role.

—Let me tell the honourable senator what I am talking about. There are pulp mill proposals for various parts of Australia. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

ANSWER.PARA: The cases of people applying for entry to Australia under the special humanitarian program are being considered and processed in the normal way. TALK.START.PARA: —The statement to which Senator Chaney refers is about a technical mission which is being sent to Scandinavia, and probably to Canada, to look at the effects of pulp mills on the environment. That is what it is about. The statement that the role of the Commonwealth will be confined to the effects of effluents on the receiving environment means that, in terms of issues such as visual impact-

—Smell, and things like that, we are not concerned.
—That is not effluent in the receiving environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
